results.title: The Portland Star
results.brief_description: Local residents and theatre workers talk about the positive impact the Portland Star has made on their lives and reminisce about “rolling Jaffas down the aisle”. Even though the theatre has seen changes over the years, in 2008 offering live music as a means to keep going, the proprietor expresses his passion for the cinema, even when it sometimes runs at a loss, and why he will continue to serve the community with great movies and live events.

results.title: The Lorne Theatre
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Established over 90 years ago, the Lorne Theatre came about when a travelling picture show man ran out of funds and some local business men purchased his equipment and started running movies in the local hall. It then moved to its present site in 1937, where for such a small permanent population, the theatre has not changed much in all those years. Tony Hill, Manager of the Lorne Theatre, talks about the difficulties in offering a diverse range of cinema in the climate of DVDs and downloadable movies, and operating in a town prone to blackouts. He is proud the theatre is attended by a local group of cinephiles who sit in the same seat every session, and thinks himself very lucky to have his job.

results.title: The Capitol
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Capitol Theatre plays a vital part in the social life of Warrnambool. Built in 1929 and opened in 1930, in 2008 the cinema has been converted into three separate cinemas, run by General Manager, Greg Gent. Taking us on a tour of the historic cinema, Gent discusses the challenges of running a cinema in the DVD age.
Stan and Norma Stevens have been associated with the cinema for over 50 years where Stan first worked as an usher and the cinema was the setting for their first date. Noel Hallam worked at the theatre for 34 years and Ivan Berndt has been the projectionist for 37 years. Each has their own stories to tell on how the theatre has been an integral part of their lives and how it continues to be.

results.title: Straford video memories
results.creator_credit: John Straford, Frank Straford and Inala Video
results.brief_description:
Video memories of the Victorian west coast and bushfires in the north-east produced by the Straford family.
“Gone to blazes” contains footage broadcast by national and commercial TV channels during the course of the devastating bushfires that ravaged the Victorian north-east early in 2003.

results.title: Olinda festival, 1952: festival presentations (CD)
results.brief_description: Audio recording of the 1952 Olinda Festival (later known as the Melbourne Film Festival), attended by over 600 film enthusiasts at two venues - Olinda and Sassafras - 26/01/1952 to the 28/01/1952. Interviewees: A. F. Bottomley, Pat Hanna, Stanley Hanna. Speakers include: G. S. Browne, Wilfred Selwyn Kent Hughes, Alan Ken Stout.

results.title: Making multicultural Australia: a multimedia documentary (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Board of Studies. Interactive Design Group
results.brief_description: Multiculturalism can mean many different things - these CD-ROMs allow you to explore many ideas and hear people from many different perscpectives putting their points of view. View a documenatry, take part in a debate, see a festival of multicultural arts, explore the “Harvest of Endurance” history scroll and read more than 2,500 pages of printable reports, documents and newspaper articles.

results.title: Lore of the land (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: Adele Howard, Multimedia 21 Fund - Cinemedia and Fraynework Multimedia
results.brief_description: The land we live in shapes our lives and holds the story of our relationship with its vast mystery. This CD ROM is an invitation to explore and understand the Aboriginal love of the land. Take a journey through new cultural insights, Australian landscapes and Indigenous voices. It is designed to encourage us to live in harmony with each other and with the land we call home. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Power Macintosh system 7.6.6 or later, 32MB RAM, 40 MB free HD space, 640 X 480 display (set to thousands of colours), 4 X CD ROM or better. IBM PC and Compatible: Pentium 200 or better, Windows 95 or later, 32MB RAM, 40MB free HD space, 640 X 480 SVGA display set to 16-bit colour (thousands), 4 X CD ROM. To run the videos on this CD ROM, you will need to instal Apple Quicktime Version 4 on your computer (contained on CD ROM).

results.title: The Face of North Sydney (PC)
results.brief_description: This disc contains over 3,700 photographs, the full text of “Naming North Sydney” (an historical dictionary of place names) and the full text of 24 heritage leaflets. It has been produced by North Sydney Council’s Stanton Library. The Local Studies Collection, from which the photographs are taken is located within the library (234 Miller Street, North Sydney).

results.title: Learning Walmajarri (PC & MAC) (A)
results.creator_credit: Catholic Education Office of Western Australia
results.brief_description: SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: PC; Multimedia capable Pentium running Windows 95.16 megabytes RAM, (32 megabytes RAM recommended). Monitor 640 x 480 resolution, 16 bit colour (thousands of colours), 8X CD drive or faster. External speakers or headphones. MAC; 68040 (30Mhz) or better (Power PC recommended) running Mac 0S 7.5 or later. Minimum of 8 megabytes FREE application RAM. DO NOT USE VIRTUAL MEMORY. Monitor 640 x 480 resolution, 16 bit colour (thousands of colours). 8X CD drive or faster. Optional external speakers or headphones. Jointly funded by the Catholic Education Office in the Kimberley region and two schools - Kururrungku Catholic Education Centre and John Pujajangka Plyrin Catholic School, ‘Learning Walmajarri’ is the result of digitising elements of the program taught by tribal elders in the Walmajarri-speaking areas around Broome. “The multimedia format of a CD is well suited to the oral tradition, which is the context in which the elders teach their language, using songs and stories to impart vocabulary and syntax”(‘The Australian’ Tuesday June 8 199 pg. 20). Designed to assist in improving literacy amongst Walmajarri speakers, this program uses jigsaws and traditional stories and songs as entertaining instruction, although people who have no previous experience with Walmajarri may be tempted to give it a try.

results.title: Discovery : Explore the world of oil & gas (MAC & PC)
results.brief_description: Take a first hand look at the oil and gas industry in Australia. You can visit areas such as; offshore production platforms, onshore gas and oil fields, witness the end use of gas and oil products, oil and gas reserves, processing products at the refinery, see how natural gas is created and trapped in the earth, and visit AMOSC (Australian Oil Spill Centre). There’s an historical overview, safety outline, and a chance to do some testing.
